title: 115_hr1692
content: The Act titled "Countering Illegal Firearms Trafficking to Mexico Act" aims to enhance collaboration between U.S. Immigrations and Customs Enforcement and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives to investigate illegal firearm trafficking to Mexico. It also includes monitoring the implementation of a 2009 Memorandum of Understanding. Additionally, the Act seeks to establish comprehensive indicators to prevent arms trafficking to Mexico. The Office of National Drug Control Policy will establish indicators to track progress in stemming arms trafficking to Mexico within 120 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, the Act addresses firearms trafficking issues. The amendment to Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, introduces new provisions regarding trafficking in firearms, making it illegal to ship, transport, transfer, or receive two or more firearms in interstate or foreign commerce if there is knowledge or reasonable cause to believe it would violate federal, state, or local laws punishable by imprisonment exceeding one year. The new provisions in Chapter 44 of title 18, US Code make it illegal to receive firearms if it violates laws punishable by imprisonment exceeding one year. It is also illegal to make false statements related to the purchase of two or more firearms that have moved in interstate or foreign commerce. It is also illegal to make false statements related to the purchase of two or more firearms that have moved in interstate or foreign commerce. Violators of these laws can face fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both. Additionally, organizers of such violations may face an additional term of imprisonment of up to 5 consecutive years if they are involved with 5 or more other individuals. The term 'actual buyer' is defined as the person for whom a firearm is being purchased, received, or acquired. The term 'actual buyer' is defined as the person for whom a firearm is being purchased, received, or acquired; and the term 'term of imprisonment exceeding 1 year' excludes misdemeanors punishable by 2 years or less. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 44 of title 18, US Code. SEC. 5 amends Section 923(g)(3)(A) of title 18, US Code to require federal firearms licensees to report multiple sales of firearms. SEC. 6 mandates the public availability of detailed information about firearms seized by Mexico and submitted for tracing by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives. SEC. 7 specifies the effective date of the provisions. The Act and its amendments will take effect 30 days after enactment.
